results.title: Win, lose or draw
results.creator_credit: Graeme MacLeod, Heather Williams, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Excalibur Nominees
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The staging of the Americas Cup in Fremantle had a huge impact on the redevelopment of Perth’s old seaport. Heritage buildings were restored, some lovingly, some superficially and new tourist and shopping precincts were created. This program explores the short and long-term effects of the development on the people of Fremantle, both rich and poor, businessmen and tenants and should give valuable lessons to others planning major redevelopment around a once-off major event such as the Americas Cup.

results.title: What's mad to you? Part 2. New approaches
results.creator_credit: Barbara A. Chobocky, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A group of psychiatrists and counsellors who offer alternative kinds of psychiatric help talk about their methods. They all stress that the need for change has to come from the patients themselves and that any change is likely to be small and not likely to happen quickly. Some of their patients also talk about their treatment and we are shown brief glimpses of sessions between therapist and patient.

results.title: What's mad to you? Part 1: Glimpses from psychiatrists
results.creator_credit: Barbara A. Chobocky, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The first in a two-part series, this program looks at the stigma associated with mental illness, particularly in relation to migrants who have different value systems. A number of psychologists and psychiatrists from a wide variety of ethnic backgrounds talk about the problems as they see it. The patient’s point of view is also presented by a small group who talk about how they overcame their resistance to seeking psychiatric help.

results.title: Nothing in writing from Captain Cook
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
In northern Australia the Aboriginal Land Council works with Aboriginal communities to reclaim traditional land and sacred sites, as well as to develop self-sufficient communities run by indigenous people. This video examines a number of Aboriginal communities along the Daly River in North-western Australia which have proven to be successful examples of Aboriginal self-determination. Examples include the Peppimenarti station which is a large station that offers both employment and accommodation to a growing number of land workers.

results.title: Lost wax memory
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Phillip Piperides, an Australian Cypriot is a sculptor in bronze. He explains the lost wax process of casting in bronze and explains the appeal of this particular form of sculpture. Shows examples of his work in Brisbane.

results.title: No turning back
results.creator_credit: Sue Richter, Georgia Allen and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A group of teenagers from a South Australian high school take part in the “Sharing our future” celebrations, a week of activities organised by the Office of Multicultural Affairs to celebrate the diversity of culture in Australia. By organising dance and drama performances together, and getting involved in discussions to do with what it means to be Australian, the young people come to appreciate the richness that cultural diversity has brought to their country. “No turning back” features songs by Gondwanaland and Midnight Oil and a special appearance by Jimmy Barnes.

results.title: Things I call mine

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Immigrants from a variety of backgrounds talk about the personal belongings they brought with them, why they brought those particular items and the memories they evoke. The interviews are intercut with a dramatisation of a young woman arriving in a new country and arranging her personal possessions in her room.

results.title: Buddha wish me luck
results.creator_credit: Sally Ingleton, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Erwin, a refugee from Hungary and his wife Samran, whom he met on a trip to Thailand live near Darwin. They describe their separate experiences as immigrants to Australia, their life together and the small tropical fruit farm that they own. Erwin is a loner, who likes nothing better than to go off hunting crocodiles, or fishing, but his wife Samran enjoys the human contact and busyness of the market where she sells her fruit. A tantalising glimpse into a marriage between two quite different people.

results.title: Talking to the Moon
results.creator_credit: Franco Di Chiera, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A group of Australians are taken back to the quarantine station which was their first experience of their new country when they arrived as migrants. A labyrinth of cold, tiny cubicles enclosed by imposing stone walls the quarantine station was, for over 50 years, the first Australian home for thousands of immigrants. Through interviews with women and men who passed the station we gain an understanding of the hardships undergone by migrants in their initial years in a new land.

results.title: Al fresco
results.creator_credit: Mario Andreacchio, Barbara Mariotti and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
In Adelaide’s Al Fresco Gelataria the young and the single meet friends, watch the passing scene of Rundle St. or strike up new relationships. Part of Adelaide’s thriving cafe society, the patrons of Al Fresco talk about their reasons for coming there, their attitude to peer groups and peer group pressure and how they relate to each other.
